awd_titl_txt: IUCRC: Planning Grant: RIT:  Center for Smart Spaces Research (CSSR)
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart spaces are characterized by the presence of smart services built on emerging sensing, computing, and communication technologies. This planning grant will create a multi-university Center for Smart Space Research (CSSR) involving Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) and the University of California, Irvine (UCI). CSSR takes an integrated approach to make them versatile and adaptable to situations by ensuring the availability and accessibility of data, knowledge, and services. This planning grant will identify research challenges to build application-focused smart spaces. Applications encompass health and disease monitoring systems, smart buildings, public spaces and cities, mission critical systems, transportation, and others.  
 
The center’s focus will be on four main areas of relevance to industry, university, and society: creation of adaptive computing and communications infrastructure; trustworthy acquisition, processing, interpretation and sustainability of data and knowledge; and applications that span all aspects of life and the environment. RIT researchers will engage in collaborations with industrial organizations, technology developers, and users, with an objective to create proactive, scalable, secure, and efficient smart spaces. The planning grant will identify challenges and research tasks to make smart spaces adaptable to multiple applications.  Collaborations with industry will lead to the emergence of new applications of smart spaces.  
 
The planning phase of CSSR will significantly impact research directions and pedagogical activities at RIT. The research activities will be fine-tuned to enable effective transfer of research artifacts to the collaborating industries with an emphasis on applications to improve quality of life, enhance public health, conserve energy, and sustainability. Workshops and interactions with industry collaborators will be leveraged to recruit and mentor diverse groups of students.   At RIT, students from diverse backgrounds, including those from the National Institute for the Deaf (NTID) will be exposed to challenges and solutions in the research and development of smart spaces.
 
In the near future, access to smart spaces and smart infrastructure will impact every individual and will greatly improve quality of life. CSSR activities in fostering innovation in accessible smart spaces will play a major role in the future world. Planning phase will serve as a platform for meetings, discussions, and workshops, to identify critical research to guide the development of smart spaces. CSSR will maintain a publicly-accessible repository comprising meeting materials, workshop information, research topics and details, and publications. This repository will be maintained at a publicly accessible URL at RIT for the lifetime of the center.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The planning grant aimed to initiate the creation a vibrant multi-university nationwide center called CSSR (Center for Smart Space Research) under the National Science Foundation’s (NSF) Industry University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) program. Led by the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) in partnership with the University of California Irvine (UCI), as well as a number of industry partners, This planning grant for the proposed CSSR center investigated a range of technologies and  tools in the area of smart spaces and gaps that hinder the widespread applicability and deployment of emerging technologies (IoT, big data, wireless networking, AI) for smartspace applications.  CSSR will provide a nationwide forum for meetings, discussions and workshops (both virtual and in-person), to identify critical research and development problems in the fertile area of smart spaces.  The Center for Smart Space Research (CSSR, pronounced Caesar) ) is organized to serve as a synergistic environment for researchers from academia and industries to spearhead research advances in multiple dimensions of smart spaces, including efficiency, scalability, energy conservation and security. We define smart spaces as any infrastructure, location, building or human that is capable of proactive and reactive actions to change in its environment and performance, efficiency, reliability and security demands.Smart spaces are characterized by the presence of smart things as in the Internet of Things (IoT), smart phones, sensors, edge devices, and RFID enabled and other entities capable of one or more of the following functionalities - sensing, computing, and communicating. While smart spaces encompass IoT and Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS), they are envisioned to utilize available resources efficiently and effectively, in a given space to create application level services. Existing smart homes, smart warehouses, smart hospitals have been designed to perform effectively to meet certain objectives that drive operations in these specific domains. In general, existing CPS and  IoT components are deployed for a single or a narrow set of applications. In many cases, the devices/things that are part of the system remain idle for most of the time, and not adopted widely by organizations and users].  Their adoption faces many challenges - interoperability,  reusability, security and privacy, robustness, and efficiency. With a view to address these challenges, we propose to create a Center for Smart Space Research (CSSR).  Initially, the center will have 2 sites: RIT will be the lead site, with a partner site at the University of California, Irvine. 

 During the planning grant phase, we conducted a range of activities including seeking potential industry partners through a discovery process.  A part-time staff member, Sabine Kunrath, was hired at UCI to help out with the process of partner discovery and to help with the logistics of the numerous meetings both for UCI and RIT.  Local PIs and staff went through the bootcamp material provided by NSF to understand the discovery process.  Numerous  meetings (over 200) with industry partners from diverse verticals and layers of the technology stack provided us with insight on what would be useful projects to incorporate into the proposed center. The academic team visited local industry partners and engaged with them in understanding their market, goals and needs.   This led to the definition of a set of projects that were formulated and further refined with the help of our industry partners. . All of these activities led to a planning meeting with several stakeholders/partners to select a subset of the proposed projects.  A Phase 1 proposal was submitted. 

A planning workshop for the center was held virtually on April 11 and 12, 2022. The meeting was co-hosted by RIT and UCI; the NSF team, and representatives from 18 organizations attended the meeting, in addition to about 50 faculty and students from the two universities. Interpreters were also present throughout the meeting to translate in American Science Language (ASL) for faculty from the National Institute for the Deaf (NTID) at RIT. Project proposals were presented and shared with all attendees; Several students from both UCI and RIT presented posters on ongoing work related to the proposed projects. This was followed by  closed-door discussions and voting by the industry members. Based on the voting the top 6 out of 10 proposed projects were selected to be performed at CSSR as noted in Intellectual Merits. The projects that were not selected for immediate pursuance were titled, “Data Staging in Smart Environments”, “Integrated At-Home Physical and Mental Health”, “Smart Spaces for Behavioral Health” and “Dynamic Neural Pipelines for Real-Time IoT Systems”. Subsequently, the UCI and RIT team worked together to refine projects selected by the IAB members for the initial round of the Phase 1 proposal.    The project identified multiple broader impact and educational opportunities for students and researchers at both institutions. Follow-up workshops were organized and held with partners following the submission of the Phase 1 proposal to keep the industry partners engaged in ongoing work.
